note.p: Alexander K. Davis was a representative in the Mississippi legislature and served as the state’s lieutenant governor from 1874 to 1876, during Reconstruction. He was the first African American lieutenant governor of Mississippi.

Little was recorded of Davis’ past. His date and place of birth are not known. During testimony before Congress in 1871 he explained that he moved to Noxubee County, Mississippi, from Tennessee in 1869, and said he had been admitted to the bar (a reference that he had been accepted as a practicing attorney in a city or county), but did not specify in which state. He won a seat in Mississippi’s House of Representatives shortly after coming to Mississippi and became a leading figure in the state’s Republican Party circles. In 1873, Radical Republicans backed by a majority of African American voters in Mississippi, won a series of state elections. Davis was one of three African Americans elected to statewide office that year, winning the lieutenant governor seat. (The other Black figures to win statewide election were James Hill as secretary of state and T. W. Cardozo as state superintendent of education.) The following year, white conservatives carried out a campaign of intimidation and violence to suppress Republican and African American voting and put Democrats into political power. The effort worked and by 1875, Democrats held a majority of state legislative seats. Emboldened by their political power, Democrats tried to rid Republicans from many state positions. They specifically targeted Davis and northern-born and Radical Republican Governor Adelbert Ames, accusing both men of improprieties in office. Davis was charged with illegal granting of pardons. Despite his effort to fight the trumped-up charges, Mississippi Democrats impeached Davis in March 1876. Knowing that the conviction would result in him being removed from office, Davis resigned. Governor Ames, also facing politically-driven impeachment proceedings that would require extensive time and financial resources to fight, resigned as well. Following his resignation, Davis abandoned politics. He moved to Canton, Mississippi and worked as a pastor. He died on November 21, 1884.
(Wikipedia; Dernoral Davis, "Alexander K. Davis," Mississippi Encyclopedia; Clyde Tucker, “Alexander K. Davis (?-1884),” Black Past)

note.p: Robert Gleed was a Republican politician, member of the Lowndes County militia, merchant, and civic leader.

The father of at least four children, Gleed was born around 1836 in Virginia. He was enslaved until the end of the Civil War in 1865 and was forced to relocate to Mississippi at some point during his enslavement.

During the war, Gleed attempted to escape but was arrested in Columbus, Lowndes County, Mississippi in 1863. In 1869, he became an alderman in Columbus. The following year, Gleed won his bid for the state senate, and he became active in the struggle for equal rights. In 1871, he testified against southern newspapers and the Ku Klux Klan for their roles in stirring up violence against Black families. The following year, he was forcibly removed from a railroad car for taking a seat in a segregated section. In 1873, following the lynching of seven "recalcitrant Blacks," he became a lieutenant colonel in the Lowndes County militia, resigned his position in the senate, and ran for sheriff. The next year, Gleed was charged with the assualt and battery of G.T. Smith but was pardoned, and in 1875, he ran for sheriff again but fled Mississippi after an attack on his home and the burning of his property.

He moved his family to Paris, Texas but did return to Mississippi from 1883 to 1885 as a lecturer on economics, morality and education for the Earnest Workers Association. Fleeing renewed threats against him, Gleed returned to Texas where he died in Harris County on July 24, 1916. He was buried in the Sandfield Cemetery in Columbus, Mississippi.

(Wikipedia; "Robert Gleed," Against All Odds: The First Black Legislators in Mississippi; The Natchez Democrat, May 18, 1869; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, January 8, 1870; The Vicksburg Herald, April 16, 1872; The Clarion Ledger, November 6, 1873; The Vicksburg Herald, September 17, 1873; The Clarion Ledger, September 8, 1875; The Vicksburg Post April 24, 1885)

Currently located in Lowndes County, Columbus was founded on December 6, 1819 in what was then a "non-county area." When Lowndes County was created on January 30, 1830, Columbus became its county seat. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

div.p:
To His Excellency
Lt Gov. A. K. Davis
Acting Governor

The undersigned citizens of the County of Lowndes in said State respectfully represent to your Excellency that at the November Term 1874 of the Circuit Court of said County an indictment was returned by the Grand Jury against Hon. Robert Gleed for assault and battery with intent to kill one G. T. Smith numbered 3781 on the docket of said Court, and also that an indictment for perjury numbered 3800 in the docket, was also returned From what we know of the facts of these cases we believe they were instigated chiefly by partisan prejudice and that they cannot be and ought not to be prosecuted or sustained. Therefore we petition your Excellency to grant a full pardon to said Robert Gleed for such alleged offences

R. Gleed
E. A. Richards
M. W. Moore
B B Eggleston
B m Littleton
[?] [?] Bishop
Without knowledge of the facts I join in the petition.

G. H. Whinfield
G. W. Van Hook
S. G. Garrett
Rev A H Dickson
S S Mitchell
Capt M. A. Brownlee
Application of pardon of Robert Gleed of Lowndes County Indicted for Perjury and Assult & battery with intent to kill
Pardon grantd by Lieut Gov. A. K Davis Actg Gov
